Posts.Content: Twiceasnice wrote: Hi Ladies: I've been on tamox for 2 1/2 years and after seeing my oncologist this week, I'm about 90 percent certain I'm gong to have at least my ovaries removed--possibly my uterus too (though I'm concerned about pelvic prolapse) I was going to wait until the 3-yr mark of Tamoxifen, but I've had 2 close girlfriends diagnosed with cancer (one is triple negative BC) and I think the time is right. Am I being overreactive? Do most people with my path:  ER+ PR + and HER2+, node positive, get their ovaries removed? I've been on Zoladex for 2 years. Does anyone have thoughts on ooferectomy vs ooferectomy AND hysterectomy? My doctor might switch me from Tamox to an AI based on the Pfizer erometase study and the MA17 study. Does anyone have personal experience with the switch before the 5-year mark of being on Tamox? Thank you! Dx 10/26/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 3, 3/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Ooferectomy or Oof & Hysterectomy Twiceasnice karen1956

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 12:08PM Twiceasnice wrote: I has my oof in Dec 2012 and have been on Tamoxifen about 2 years. I am seeing my oncologist tomorrow to discuss switching to an aromotase inhibitor since I hear studies show good outcomes for those with their ovaries removed after 2 or so years on Tamox. Any questions I should ask or issues I should be concerned about in switching? Thanks!
Posts.Title: Ooferectomy or Oof & Hysterectomy Twiceasnice karen1956

Posts.Content: Twiceasnice wrote: I was just reviewing the second path report done on my original tumor slides (the first was done at a regional hospital) the second at an academic institution and is much more detailed. While the treatment remains the same, there is a LOT more detail and some minor differences from the first report. The docs never really explained these differences to me, and I was hoping that between this forum and google, I could get some help in translation.   And figure out the significance, if any, of some of these tumor features...Thanks!  Here goes:  ER 80% PR 70% HER 2 + immunohistochemistry 3 + Poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma involving the dermis of the nipple and an associated component of ductal carcinoma in situ (from the second report) Invasive Ductal Carcinoma with focal lobular features Mitotic index of 2 per high power field  Pernineural invasion present Tumor invading angiolymphatic spaces in the breast parenchyma and within dermal lymphatics  Surgical margins positive DCIS grade 2-3/3 by SBR Criteria compromising  5 % of the sample  No lymphovascular invasion   Metastatic carcinoma in 4/5 sentinel nodes. None of the other axillary lymph nodes were positive  Dx 10/26/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 3, 3/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Translating Path Report Twiceasnice Lilah

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 09:06PM Twiceasnice wrote: Thanks everyone for the replies and information. Lilah--my new BFF :-) Good catch--I asked the same thing when it came back. Two different hospitals reviewed the slides and they said sometimes the nodes "stick" together when they cut them out of the fatty pack. That's why one report shows 5, the other 4. Unfortunately, due to changing guidelines, it didn't make a difference with respect to radiation. It was still recommended at 4 or 5 affected nodes.  Thanks again ladies---
Posts.Title: Translating Path Report Twiceasnice Lilah

Posts.Content: Twiceasnice wrote: Hi all It's been a while since I've been here and it feels so good to be back . I just marked 4-yrs since my diagnosis on 10/29. Yay! (BTW what date is used for survival rates is it the date when chemo ended?) I need some words of encouragement Six months ago, I lost my mom and sister in the same week. My mom was diagnosed with small cell lung cancer and she died 2 1/2 weeks later: My sister took her life the week my mom died. I never really went back to work full time since treatment ended. I worked PT but really enjoyed life and traveled making enough to get by but taking time away from a stressful PR career in the nations capital Now the money is about to run out and I'm looking for aFT job in my career to earn enough to get back on my feet I'm not really stressed but I'm feeling the heat so to speak. I could use ( a job) but really words of encouragement or advice Hugs to all Dx 10/26/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 3, 3/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 4-yr Anniversary Twiceasnice karen1956

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2013 02:15AM Twiceasnice wrote: thank you. More media relations/ communications but worked a lot with lobbyists. I've weighed whether to move to a different city (Boston, NYC, west coast) but feel like I can't mess around anymore.) (:-
